indicators.justification:
Unfortunately, the Ministry of Environment has a negative reputation in Romania and internationally in terms of the management of protected species living in the country. In the Guidelines for conserving connectivity through ecological networks and corridors, IUCN criticizes Romania for the way it manages its natural heritage, due to pollution caused by investments in the electricity generation industry, for example, protected species are endangered. (1) Environmental organizations are the entities that constantly fight for the protection of the environment, flora and fauna, blocking polluting projects by suing the Romanian state. For example, Bankwatch Romania and Agent Green managed in 2020 to block in the first court the project for the construction of the Bumbești - Livezeni Hydropower Plant, built in the middle of the Jiu Gorge National Park. The biggest controversy in Romania regarding the management of endangered species is that although it is part of the Platform on Coexistence between People and Large Carnivores, and the hunting of bear trophies is banned nationally since 2016, the Ministry of Environment proves lack of transparency in that the rules on hunting derogations are ambiguous and the selection of specimens is left to the discretion of hunting associations. In other words, being a protected species - a bear (male only) can be hunted only if it is a danger. However, due to the lack of regulations on the selection of the specimen in question, hunting associations that receive derogations often hunt large specimens, which can be considered trophies, not specimens that are really a problem. Thus, a problem that endangers both human life and the welfare of the species remains.
(1)	IUCN, Guidelines for conserving connectivity through ecological networks and corridors, https://portals.iucn.org/library/sites/library/files/documents/PAG-030-En.pdf
(2)	Agent Green, press release on bear trophy hunting allowed by the Ministry of Environment https://www.agentgreen.ro/ministerul-mediului-pe-cale-de-a-deschide-sezonul-la-vanatoarea-ursilor-pentru-trofee/

Romania's level of transparency regarding public finances and the publication of budget data is quite high. The Ministry of Public Finance operates a portal on which it uploads all the financial reports of the Romanian public entities in open formats.(1)
According to law no. 69/16 April 2010 on fiscal-budgetary responsibility, Chapter IX on the transparency of fiscal-budgetary policy, the Government and local public authorities have the obligation to make public and maintain in debate for a reasonable period of time all necessary information to assess the implementation of fiscal and budgetary policies, their results and the state of central and local public finances. (2) Within 45 days from the publication of the state budget law and the state social insurance budget law in the Official Gazette of Romania, the Ministry of Public Finance publishes on its own website the data on public debt, according to the European Union methodology, but also financial programming quarterly of state budget expenditures, state social insurance budget and special funds budgets, in economic classification, based on the quarterly budget revenue collection program. And within 55 days of the adoption of the budgets, the Ministry of Public Finance publishes on its website the quarterly estimates regarding the expenditures of the local budgets, the budgets of the self-financed institutions and other components of the general consolidated budget. The classification of indicators on public finances in force was approved by Order 1954 / 16.12.2005, with subsequent amendments and completions, and can be found at:https://mfinante.gov.ro/domenii/bugetul-de-stat/clasificatiile-bugetare (3)

indicators.justification:
Although at national and European level there is not yet a law that deals directly and exhaustively with "data-sharing", there are parts of laws and regulations that refer to the transfer of data between entities, whether we are referring here to the transfer data within sectors or from one sector to another. LAW no. 363 of December 28, 2018 on protection natural persons regarding the processing of data with personal data by the competent authorities in the purpose of prevention, discovery, investigation, prosecution and combating crime or the execution of sentences, educational and safety measures, as well as on free movement of this data (1) is the law that treats some of the data-sharing aspects in Romania. It was adopted after entering into force of the EU Regulation 2016/679. This law is especially applied when the personal data sharing occurs between public institutions. Regarding the sharing between private entities, the EU Regulation 2016/679 has a whole chapter about the transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations (chapter V). The European Commission launched in November 2020 the proposal for a Regulation on European data governance (Data Governance Act) in order to increase the trust in data intermediaries and to strengthen the data-sharing mechanisms across the EU (2). Before that, in February 2020, the Commission launched the European Data Strategy, with the purpose to create a single market for data for the benefit of businesses, researchers and public administrations (3). Data Governance Act remains still as a proposal, because there are parts that breach the GDPR law.
As of 2018, Regulation (EU) 2018/1807 on a framework for the free flow of non-personal data in the European Union applies to all Member States (4). Together with the Open Data Directive, important parts of what "data sharing" means are covered, but the two normative acts often conflict with GDPR legislation, whereby almost any information can be considered personal.
Therefore, the issue of data sharing in Romania is a complicated one to address, due to the multiple legislative conflicts between data transfer and personal data protection.

Regarding compliance with the Regulation during the Covid-19 pandemic, on the 21st of April 2020, the European Data Protection Board adopted Guidelines 4/2020 on the use of location data and contact tracing tools in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak, that established for the tracking apps not to involve the use of location data, but only proximity data (3).
In 2019, the National Authority received a total of 6193 complaints, intimation and notifications regarding security incidents, based on which 912 investigations were opened. As a result of the investigations carried out, 28 fines were applied in a total amount of 2,339,291.75 lei (meaning approximately 475,461.12 euros). indicators.justification:
Currently, in Romania, Law no. 109/2007 is in force, regarding the re-use of information from public institutions, updated in 2015 with more extensive and comprehensive clauses through Law no. 299/2015 (1). As Romania is a member of the EU, with the approval by the European Parliament of Directive 2019/1024, (2) our country is obliged to transpose the European normative act into national legislation by July 2021. At that moment, the Law 109/2007 will be repealed, the current draft law transposing the EU Directive, launched in public debate at the beginning of 2021 and that will be soon debated in the Romanian Parliament, will enter into force (3). The public institutions in charge with the transposition of the EU Directive are the Authority for the Digitization of Romania and the Minister of Research, Innovation and Digitalization.
In the current legislation – Law no. 109/2007, Article 4 contains the definitions that apply to the important terms used, among which we mention: public institution, document, reuse, open format, automatic processable format, etc. There is no a standard definition for "open data" but the term can be understood from context and the other definitions. The new draft law transposing the EU Directive contains such a precise definition in Article 2, paragraph 8.
Law no. 109/2007 specifies in Article 9 that in order to facilitate the access and search of documents provided in electronic and automatically processable format, public institutions must publish the documents to which the law applies also on the governmental open data portal -data.gov.ro-, together with metadata relevant, in compliance with the rules for its use. The portal was launched in 2013, and in 2015 the Guide for publishing Open Data was launched by the Prime Minister's Chancellery and the Coalition for Open Data (a coalition of civil society organizations).
Art. 6-7 refer to the people or institutions interested in certain data may request them from the institution that has them, the response term is 20 days. The institution is obliged to respond to the applicant, the information may be made available to the applicant in full or in part; if only part of information will be sent, a motivation will be made on this decision. 
Law no. 109/2007 specifies in Article 6 that the requesters may specify in the application the format in which they wish the documents. To the extent that public institutions approve the re-use of the documents in their possession, they shall be made available to the applicant, in any pre-existing format or in any available language and, if possible and appropriate, in open and automatically processable formats, together with their metadata. Both formats and metadata should, as far as possible, comply with open format standards. Public institutions are not obliged to create, adapt documents or provide extracts from documents if this would require disproportionate costs, which go beyond the scope of a simple operation. Many standards, that now lack from the national legislation, will be implemented by the future law transposing the EU Directive, in the next months. Regarding the training and capacity building, the draft law mentions it and puts an accent on it, and more than that in the last years in Romania there were implemented projects that teach public servants TIC instruments properly.

Law 544/2001 on free access to information of public interest was adopted following the adoption of the acquis Communautaire, in the process of Romania's accession to the European Union. 
According to its provisions, any public institution has the obligation to make available to citizens, upon request, information on their own activity that do not refer to categories such as: national security, personal data, judicial investigations, etc. The information must be provided within 10 days. In case of requesting more complex information, the term can be extended to 30 days, with the prior notice of the applicant. If the request has not been addressed to the appropriate institution, the law enforcement officer is required to tell the applicant the appropriate authority. (1)
Law no. 52/2003, the law of decisional transparency, applies to the central and local public administration authorities, elected or appointed, as well as to other public institutions that use public financial resources - town halls, local and county councils, ministries, Supreme Council of Magistracy, etc. In essence, the meetings and debates of public institutions are public, the minutes of these meetings must be recorded and made public. Draft decisions must be made known to the public 30 days before the decision is taken, the notice of intent must be published on the institution's website and posted on its website, given to the media and to all persons who have submitted a request for this information. The institution must wait at least 10 days to receive suggestions. (2)
